reviewText: Bret "Hit Man" Hart was, in the early-to mid 1990s, the leader of the new school. Before him, WWE Champions were big, hulking guys who depended on power and force. Bret was a mat technician who picked opponents of all shapes and sizes apart. He paved the way for future champions like Shawn Michaels, Kurt Angle, Chris Jericho, Chris Benoit, and even Rey Mysterio. Bret was just the man. His trademark pink and black, the glasses, the music, the no-nonsense attitude. Bret just took care of business.Bret indeed was a great wrestler, and it's a shame that his career has come to an end. The documentary on this DVD hits the surface very well, telling the complete Hitman story. Bret does most of the storytelling, giving a very intimate look at the many facets of his career. It's a shame that he's still bitter about the infamous screwjob in 1997, but it's great that he and Vince McMahon were able to come together to produce this long-overdue tribute to an incredible career.Even though the documentary hits all the right spots, the rest of the DVD falls flat. The matches Bret hand-picked show how great of a wrestler he is. But some of them are just plain boring. I haven't watched all of them yet because I keep falling asleep. Bret, I love you and prefer you over Shawn Michaels anyday. But you've got to include him in the match list. At least the match you won, at  the 1992 Survivor Series. Too often during the DVD I get the impression that Bret thinks a little too highly of himself. He's a little too much like "See, I'm better than Shawn. Vince never shoulda screwed me!" I keep feeling that Bret still lets his nasty end in the WWE diminish the great things he did. He led a generation. He carried the WWE after Hogan left. He, along with Kurt Angle, Ric Flair, and Chris Benoit, is one of the most impressive mat wrestlers the industry will ever see. So why the hell is he so bitter? LET IT GO, BRET!!!Nonetheless, it was great to see this collection finally get released. Bret will always be considered a top-tier performer in the world of wrestling. Nothing can ever change that.
summary: Great documentary on one of wrestling's biggest stars

reviewText: I am so excited about the release of this DVD collection about the best of Bret "The Hitman" Hart. It's amazing that this is going to be released because, after Bret split with WWE in 1997, it looked as if the two would never reunite...a longshot at best. But, we can now enjoy Bret's career on what looks to be a very solid collection. Here are some reasons why this should be a good buy:1. It highlights Bret Hart's entire career, not just his days in WWF (now WWE). In addition to his days with the World Wrestling Federation, the DVD covers his days in Stampede Wrestling and WCW, so you will get the "full-version" of the Hitman.2. Nearly every classic Bret Hart match is included. Some of his all-time best include:-vs. Mr. Perfect for the Intercontinental title, Summerslam 1991.-vs. "British Bulldog" Davey Boy Smith for the Intercontinental title, Summerslam 1992.-vs. Owen Hart, Wrestlemania X (1994).-vs. Diesel for the WWE title, Survivor Series 1995.-vs. British Bulldog for the WWE Championship, In Your House V (Dec 1995).-vs. Steve Austin, Submission match, Wrestlemania XIII (1997).I do think that they could have included one or two other classic matches, such as the one against Shawn Michaels for the WWE title at Survivor Series 1992 (the first time), but the list covers mostly all of the best.3.  Bret himself provides his personal insight and reflection on his illustrious career, speaking about things such as the falling out w/ WWF in 1997, the death of his brother Owen, his family life and his early wrestling career, and much more.There you are! Three reasons why this should be a great DVD to add to the collection. Many WWE DVD's covering the history of a superstar have fallen short of expectations. I feel, though, that this one will be excellent and will be plenty for any fan of Bret Hart.If you like Bret, then this is a great DVD for you!

reviewText: The Hitman finally gets his own dvd set. And I must say it was well worth the wait.This DVD stars out with an excellent & detailed documentary. I will say that it covers his entire career.The matches:Before I begin, just wanna say that they let Bret choose the matches that were on here. They should do that for every wrestler.Hart Foundation vs. British Bulldogs (Madison Square Garden, 07/13/85) - A great match. This is when tag teams meant something unlike now. I don't know why but I'm not used to seeing these kinds of matches. Now, I've seen tag matches before. Many of them. Just something about this particular bout. Maybe the camera angle and/or ring? I don't know.... What I do know (other than this was a great match) is that this took place 2 months and 8 days before I was born lol.Hart Foundation vs. Killer Bees (Madison Square Garden, 02/17/86) - Another great one. Before seeing this, I forgot about the Killer Bees tag team.Bret Hart vs. Ricky Steamboat (Boston Garden, 03/08/86) - When you get 2 great wrestlers, you're bound to see a really good effort from them. This was certainly no exception.Bret Hart vs. Ted DiBiase (Odessa, TX, 03/08/89)- A wonderfully worked one on one match.Hart Foundation vs. Rockers (Saturday Night's Main Event, 04/28/90) - A tremendous tag match. Had this been given more time & had Demolition not interfered during the match, it'd be a much better match. Hell, a classic even.WWE Tag Team Championship MatchHart Foundation vs. Nasty Boys (Wrestlemania VII, 03/24/91)- I liked this match. I was upset when I first saw this way back when that The Hart Foundation lost. But, I was happy seeing Bret get his long awaited singles push that ended with him beating The Nature Boy for his first World Championship.WWE Intercontinental MatchBret Hart vs. Mr. Perfect (SummerSlam, 08/26/91)- Normally, I'm not a fan of matches that are already released being released again (especially when it's part of a ppv that can easily be bought) but this is one of the few exceptions. To say this is a CLASSIC describes this PERFECTLY. These two always had classics.WWE Intercontinental MatchBret Hart vs. British Bulldog (SummerSlam, 08/29/92)- Another of the few exceptions about matches on ppv being released again. This is Bret's favorite match or so he says. I may have misheard because he's had many great, memorable classics so this is more likely one of this favorites. And mine too. Both men were faces. But Bret was booed as this took place from London, where Bulldog is from. This is an excellent match that's worth many viewings.Bret Hart vs. Bam Bam Bigelow (Barcelona, Spain, 04/24/93)- A good match. Hard for me to get into because of the commentary as I'm not fluent in Spanish. This should've added an English track or had an alternative commentary track with Bret Hart & Jim Ross.King of the Ring Semi-Final MatchBret Hart vs. Mr. Perfect (King of the Ring, 06/13/93)- Another classic here. Need I say more? Ok I will. If you have this set, watch it. If not, get it & watch it.Bret Hart vs. Owen Hart (Wrestlemania X, 03/20/94)- I loved this match. I was surprised that Owen won when I saw this on ppv. But looking back now, it made a lot of sense as Bret was wrestling for the Title anyways so a win here, while it would give him momentum, wouldn't really do much good for him. 1994 was clearly the year of Owen Hart. If they ever release a set on him, the entire year of 1994 should be on the hopefully 3 disc soon to be released/long awaited Owen Hart set.WWE Championship MatchBret Hart vs. Owen Hart (White Plains, NY, 09/29/94)- I didn't see a problem with adding this match as it is rare. But since this & their WM10 match is here, it would've made sense if their SSlam Cage match was here too.Bret Hart vs Hakushi (In Your House, 05/14/95 - A great match here. These two meshed well. Hakushi was very innovative. I still don't know to this day why he didn't last long in WWE & why WCW or ECW never picked him up.WWE Championship MatchBret Hart vs. Diesel (Survivor Series, 11/19/95) - I never knew this but apparently this is the match where the table spot happens for the first time. Bret always did quite well against anyone, including big men. This proves it.WWE Championship MatchBret Hart vs. British Bulldog (In Your House, 12/17/95)- Their SSlam 92 is their best. But this was excellent too nonetheless.Submission MatchBret Hart vs. Stone Cold Steve Austin (Wrestlemania 13, 03/23/97)- A VERY SUPERB match! Turning points of both men's career. Magic happened as a double turn took place, which I believe is one of the reasons why this match is so famous. Both men loved this match as do I. Wish their SSeries 96 match was here too. That was a great one though this was slightly better.WWE Championship MatchBret Hart vs. Undertaker (One Night Only, 09/20/97)- Personally, out of all the matches that many have probably not seen that on this set, this was my favorite as Undertaker is my favorite wrestler. Many say this was his best performance. I can't say for sure as he's called the Conscience Of The WWE & more often, The Phenom for a very good reason. To be honest though, I did like their SSlam 97 bout better. But this was right up there.Owen Hart Tribute MatchBret Hart vs. Chris Benoit (WCW Nitro, 10/04/99)- Just a classic masterpiece. Worthy of being here. A great tribute to Owen if I do say so myself.A great selection of matches. I feel some more could have been added though. I match with Jerry Lawler would have been great as their feud was famous back then. Also his KOTR93 match with Bam Bam along with the entire coronation which was interrupted by Jerry Lawler would have been great too. However, no complaints from me.There are some hidden easter eggs. Click the left arrow twice and the clip will play.Bret Hart discusses believability inside the ringOn Disc Two, Go to Chapters, Highlight 'Bret Hart vs. Ricky Steamboat'. Click the Right arrow twice. reviewText: Being a Bret Hart fan when I was a kid, when I heard they were coming out with a Bret Hart DVD, I was a little skeptical at first.  But when I read that Bret was indeed involved (unlike Ultimate Warrior with the "Self Destruction" DVD), I was anxious to get it the day it came out.  And while it was not exactly a stellar effort, it was still a well produced DVD, looking past some of the flaws.  Originally, this DVD was going to be called "Screwed: The Bret Hart Story," a "Vance" McMahon idea, but it was thankfully changed to "The Best There Is, The Best There Was, The Best There Ever Will Be."There are some negative aspects about the DVD which are mostly minor but at least some of them been corrected, I would have given this the full 5 star rating.* Wrestlemania 13/Bret Hart v. Stone Cold : There is an annoying audio error; the sound occurs half a second later or so (ex: Bret hitting mat, half a second later, you hear the BAM).  Also, I didn't like it that they omitted the other part of the ending, in which Austin stuns one of the refs after waking up from his struggle with the Sharpshooter.* I thought the extra menu on Disc 1 should've been better structured; this is a really minor thing, but each of his little extra stories were not that long, so a "PLAY ALL" feature would've been nice.* Did anyone else think it was strange that Piper said he only wrestled Bret one time?  One time in WWE, yes, but not in WCW.* Jessie "The Body" Ventura's commentary was taken out of the Rockers/Hart Foundation match, and throughout the matches they've bleeped out "WWF."* While the match selection wasn't terrible, there were some matches I had never seen that I would've liked included.  The biography shows Flair v. Bret at Saskatoon for Bret's first WWE title, but it's not under the match selection and it was only a House show.  Also, there are no matches against Shawn Michaels at all, with the exception of Hart Foundation v. Rockers; why not the first WWE Ladder match, Bret v. Shawn?  Why not have the Steel Cage Summerslam match Bret v. Owen on the match selection?  Why not have Piper v. Bret for the IC title at Wrestlemania?  Why not have his hardcore match against Terry Funk in WCW, in which Funk won?  Some of the matches, while appealing to Bret in some way I suppose, I felt were average or boring, such as Bret v. Diesel, or Bret v. Million Dollar Man (I know that that match was a tribute to Dean Hart, but still).  The Owen Hart Tribute Match is a GREAT match, but it was already on the Benoit DVD, and it could've been moved for other, rare matches.HOWEVER, there were a lot of positives as well.  I liked the rare match between Bam Bam and Bret, as well as his matches with Curt Henning.  The Wrestlemania match between Bret and Stone Cold is a classic.  The title match against Owen in which British Bulldog comes to Bret's aid is also a classic, and so is their IC title match at Summerslam (the crowd is INSANE here).  I loved the Wrestlemania match in which Owen (the underdog) beats Bret, and is probably my favorite Bret Hart match.  While the Owen Hart Tribute Match was already on the Chris Benoit DVD, it is still one of Bret's best matches.I also liked the biography; the production of it was decent and I loved Bret's interviews.  He didn't seem like a vengeful, washed up legend.  He spoke with assured trueness and reflected well on his career despite his tragedies.  He didn't seem to hold much of a grudge against Shawn Michaels, and fairly talked about him (unlike HBK about Bret in his book).  They didn't focus much on the Montreal Screwjob, which I see as a good thing; it's over and done with, and I'd prefer to remember Bret as a champion rather than a screwed wrestler.While not a perfect DVD set, it is still one of the best DVD sets to come out of the WWE.  Definitely worth between 15 and 20 dollars.  Bret Hart is truly one of the best wrestlers of all time, whether you like him or not.
summary: Thankfully not called "Screwed: The Bret Hart Story."

reviewText: This 3-DVD set chronicles the life and career of one Bret 'The Hitman' Hart. The first DVD contains the main documentary, Bret Hart Interview Moments(where he talks about the Dungeon, his sunglasses, the sharpshooter, etc), two Tribute Videos(Dean Hart and Bret's colleagues that have died), and two matches from the mid 80's in Madison Square Gardens.The other two DVD's contain all matches. The main draw of this DVD set is the unbelievably frank and open Bret Hart documentary. Unlike some of the other WWE documentaries that contain some element of "kayfabe", Bret spills his thoughts and emotions out without much reservation. It is an eye-opening experience to watch(although sometimes it can be painful, especially when you can see that Bret is about to get teary-eyed).For me, a lot of these matches I have not seen before(especially from the mid 90's when I stopped watching wrestling all together), so it was a pleasant surprise to be able to watch a lot these for the first time. I like the fact that Bret chose some obscure matches from house shows and even a 'dark match' against Dibiase with no commentators. All told this is a great and revealing DVD set of the legendary Bret 'The Hitman' Hart.

reviewText: I wasn't sure what to expect from this dvd. You can't go wrong with the list of matches, but I was nervous about the documentary part of it. I was afraid that it was going to be a "Montreal Screwjob" dvd and not a Bret Hart dvd. Thankfully, they proved me wrong. Of course, there is a Survivor Series '97 section, but they don't dwell on it. Instead, the focus remains on Bret's greatness, which he deserves.The documentary runs just over two hours, and it shows plenty of highlights from his Stampede Wrestling days. The pacing of the documentary is somewhat subtle and slow, which fits Bret Hart's personality perfectly. You won't a lot of promos because, let's face it, Bret was never known for his great mic skills. In the "Sunglasses" section, he admits that the reason he started wearing them was to hide the nervousness in his eyes during interviews.I always respected Bret, but thought of him as something of a whiner. Now I see him differently. After watching the dvd, it becomes clear that Bret Hart is a deeply quiet and sensitive man. A few times, he comes close to breaking down, and he says that after the Iron Man Match, he was hurt when HBK told him to leave the ring right away... so he can have his moment of glory. This dvd definitely gives me a new appreciation of Bret Hart, the person.

reviewText: If you have ever wondered how people can get excited, or devote their time to a "fake" sport, then you really have to check out Bret Hart's DVD. If you have ever doubted the genuine athletic ability of professional wrestlers, then you owe it to your self to watch "The Best There is....". Bret Hart may not have the mainstream name recognition of a Hulk Hogan or Ric Flair, but Bret Hart is pro wrestling personified. A real professional, both in the ring and out, and this DVD showcase is fantastic for both hardcore and casual wrestling fan alike. I grew up watching Bret Hart on WWF television, and very fond memories of the "Hitman", quite a few of my favorite matches are included in this set. I loved seeing the early Stampede wrestling footage, as well as some of his stuff that I missed with his move to WCW. My wife, who has maybe seen 15 minutes of wrestling her entire life, enjoyed "The Best There Is..." as much as I did. She was really sucked into Bret's story, which at times will have you laughing and cheering, and at other times, will have you teared up with a lump in your throat. WWE & Vince McMahon have done such a great job with these DVD collections honoring the superstars that put the company on the entertaiment radar (Self Destruction of the Ultimate Warrior aside), and Bret's story has been the most compelling so far. If you have any interest in wrestling then this dvd is must have.

reviewText: The greatest wrestler to have ever graced a squared circle finally gets to shed light on his legacy. Ever since Survivor Series '97...Bret Hart's career hasn't been labeled with the words "Excellence Of Execution" but with the word "SCREWED" and it's stayed that way for over close to 10 years and would have been kept that way for the rest of his life after the original annoucement that this DVD would be labeled "Screwed: The Bret Hart Story." However, Bret stepped up & was able to erase that word from his legacy is replace it with "Best There Is, Best There Was, Best There Ever Will Be" and also made this one of the most "unique" DVD sets in WWE history.The early years of Bret growing up in the Hart household and breaking into his dad's Stampeed Wrestling kick the documentry off. His entrance in to WWE and not really getting off to a good start (Cowboy Bret Hart?) until he finally teamed with Jim Neidhart & Jimmy Hart to form the Hart Foundation. The Hart Foundation's dominance over the tag team division as well as Bret's ability to be a heel are glossed over before his road to the Intercontinental Championship and how important that championship was to his career (which is amazing compared to how it's being used in WWE today). His classic matches featuring Roddy Piper (WrestleMania VIII & my favorite "Hitman" match), Mr. Perfect & British Bulldog (SummerSlam '91 & '92) are also looked upon leading up to his first WWE title reign (including highlights from the match with Flair that is rare to find), the impact is had on making him an international superstar, and how he was able to make to have people apprechate wrestling more over than Hulk Hogan's sports entertainment. His fued with his brother Owen is discussed after Bret discusses his disappointment in how his first title reign ended (remember Hulk Hogan at WrestleMania IX?) and how he worked his way back to the title including the King Of The Ring tournament. His disapointment in his third title reign being completely overlooked infavor of Shawn Michaels leading up to his WrestleMania XII Ironman Match. The Ironman match is heavily discussed as Bret talks about how he thought everything (promos, commentary during the match) were in favor of HBK. His return to WWE after his vacation and the heated fued between himself & Stone Cold Steve Austin is heavily discussed as well as the respect for one another. Bret's last run which provoked a U.S.A. vs. Canada fued along with the new Hart Foundation is discussed leading up to the Survivor Series. Survivor Series isn't heavily talked about but you get everyone's feelings now after they've had plently of times to reflect on their actions. Bret's disappointing run in WCW is discussed along with Bret's favorite moments including the Owen Hart tribute match. The profile on Bret rounds out with him talking about his stroke and how his life has been for the past few years.DVD extras include interview outtakes where Bret discusses certain issues like the name "The Dungeon", how Konnan taught Bret the Sharpshooter, a funny Owen story where he crankcalled Stu Hart, the story behind his sunglasses, and the whole Hart Family tree. Also Bret pays tribute to his friends in the wrestling business who passed away along with his late brother Dean Hart. Hidden extras were his "You Start The Fire" music video, an old Stampeed Wrestling interview featuring the Bushwackers (then known as the Sheepherders), and interview outtakes feauturing Bret discussing never injuring another wrestler, and where he got the name "Hitman."Matches (picked out by Bret himself) Include:Hart Foundation vs. British Bulldogs - While these two teams did have some great to classic matches against each other, I thought this match was just average at best & more like a preview of their other matches to come."MSG" July '85Hart Foundation vs. Killer Beez - This was tag "team wrestling 101" between both teams with them utilizing the same strategy of working over one member of the team while preventing the other from coming in for the save.  The Beezs worked over Niedhart for the beginning of the match before the Harts recovered & heavily cutting the ring off & isolating Jim Brunzel for a majority of the match building to the hot tag.  Not a classic encounter but it's good tag team wrestling."MSG" Feb. '86vs. Ricky Steamboat - This was always a dream match of mine but it's nice to know that this match actually did happen.  Bret was still coming into his own as a heel as he attacked Steamboat before the bell & later even delievered a slam to Steamboat on the floor.  Steamboat later recovered with his "martial arts" offense of chops before doing into a good wrestling match that saw the early potential of Bret Hart as a singles star.Mar. '86vs. Ted Dibiase - It should be noted that there was no commentary on this match.  Dibiase heavily stalled in the beginning after Bret almost got a quick victory & countering everything Dibiase threw at him.  Dibiase was able to capitalize on a big missed move by Bret and dominate for several mintues before the match got more competitive between both men as Bret pushed Dibiase to his limit as you couldn't help but notice his heavy breathing after the match.  Good match here.Mar. '89Hart Foundation vs. Rockers - The seeds of the infamous Hart/Michaels relationship were planted here as during their tag team years as the Hart Foundation were the stronger & more technical team while Rockers were the quicker & more flashy team. The match didn't go long but it followed the classic tag team wrestling formula of one team dominating with the other team building up to getting that hot tag from his partner with appearence of Demolition being a wild card here."Saturday Night's Main Event" Apr. '90("Best Of Saturday Night's Main Event")WWE Tag Team Championship Match vs. Nasty Boys - Bret Hart conciders a match against the Nasty Boys as one of his personal favorites?  I was thinking that when I first saw this but after seeing this, I could understand why because this match perfectly showcases how great the Hart Foundation were as they were able to make inferior wrestlers look better than they really were.  The Harts dominated early & did a majority of the work here while the Nasty's did what they always did best in the ring & bump around.WrestleMania VIIvs. Intercontinental Champion Mr. Perfect - This is a pure wrestling fans dream here and tons of credit here goes to Mr. Perfect for putting on this type of performance with a back injury that would keep him out of the ring for over a year. This would be the match that put Bret Hart on the map as a solo star & was also the debut of the Sharpshooter.SummerSlam '91("History Of Intercontinental Championship" & "The Life & Times Of Mr. Perfect")Intercontinental Championship Match vs. British Bulldog - This was a historic match on many levels as this was the only time that only the Intercontinental Championship main evented a PPV & this the second largest WWE crowd to date. Eventhough there were some botches (that Bret acknowledged in his DVD set), these were two of the best WRESTLERS WWE had that that time giving quite the classic performance with the "Diana Hart" factor adding to the drama of the match.SummerSlam '92("History Of Intercontinental Championship" & "Best Of Confidental Vol. 1")vs. Bam Bam Bigelow - This was a match that really showcased Bret on the defense as Bigelow used this strength to dominate Bret throughout the match while heavily focusing on his back with bear hugs, backbreakers, and even ramming it into the post.  Bret was able to recover in the final moments but again, this was a good showcase of Bret being a defensive wrestler.  It should be noted that this match has spanish commentary.Apr. '93vs. Mr. Perfect - This was a lost classic as far as the inring performance & storytelling between the two with Bret still selling his injured fingers from the earlier match & eventually both men selling the effects of their match later on with both men having injured knees. It started off as a technical match with Perfect getting real aggressive while looking for a payback from SummerSlam '91 (as aluded to in the the pre-match interview) leading to Bret turning the heat up himself. Look out for the moment when Bret Hart was sent flying off the apron onto the floor with head hitting the steel railing while his tailbone landed right on top of a crate at ringside. The match of the night here & was a lost classic until it made it's way to DVD a few years ago.King Of The Ring '93vs. Owen Hart - They started off by trying to one-up each other in the beginning with Owen having some very entertaining taunts towards Bret before both men ended up exchanging slaps to each other.  This went into a very technical match as Owen worked over Bret's back after ramming it into the steel post, doing a variation of the camel clutch, and even doing the imfamous piledriver that he did to Steve Austin years later.  The target would eventually turn towards Bret's knee with Owen using the figure four & hurting it even more with the ringpost.  Bret gained momentum back & we even had a battle of the sharpshooters before Owen was able to get one step ahead of Bret (literraly) and have what was without a doubt the breakthough performance of his career with Lawler quoting the moment perfectly, "He didn't step out...he jumped out of the shadow."WrestleMania X("Greatest Wrestling Stars Of The 90's)WWE Championship Match vs. Owen Hart - This match was the main event of the debut of another WWE/USA Network weekend afternoon show called "The Action Zone" with Vince McMahon & Todd Pettingel (god, I forgot how awful he was until I hear this match).  This was built up as Owen Hart's last title shot against Bret after so many failed attempts.  This wasn't the calibur of their PPV matches that year but a good television match here as both men went back & forth with each other while both Jim Niedhart & Davey Boy Smith would appear at ringside to lend suppost & aid to their fellow family member with "poetic justice" against Owen & Niedhart playing a factor in the end."Action Zone" Sept. '94vs. Hakushi - This was the opening match from the very first "In Your House" PPV and one of two matches Bret was scheduled to wrestle that night as he also had a match against Jerry Lawler scheduled for later that night.  For those who don't remember Hakushi, he's the japanese wrestler who would also wrestle under the name Jinsei Shinzaki & probably most remembered for his classic tag team match he had against Rob Van Dam & Sabu at ECW's Heatwave PPV in 1998.  This match was a different one than Bret usually has since Hakushi had a different offense than other WWE wrestlers at that time since he was very athletic & utilized various aerial moves like the Asai Moonsault and also did a tight-rope walk on the top ropes that makes Undertaker's "old school" look like "pre-school".  This was a nice encounter but really seemed like it was missing something to really make it standout or memorable."In Your House" May '95No Holds Barred Match vs. WWE Champion Diesel - The match could only end in pinfall or submission due to their last two matches not having a clear winner. This match made history...as this was the first time a wrestler went thought the spanish announce table which would become a WWF tradition for the next couple of years. This was one of the most physical matches in both mens careers as they not only used various weapons against each other (steel exposed turnbuckles, steel chairs, camera cords) but they just beat on each other in what was a slow physical brawl mixed with some good wrestling. Bret would regain the title in the end.Survivor Series '95WWE Championship Match vs. British Bulldog - It took over 3 years but this is the rematch to their famous encounter from SummerSlam '92 however the circumstances in this match were completely different than their previous one.  Bulldog was a full time heal managed by Jim Cornette & unlike how Diana Hart (Bulldog's wife & Bret's sister) was mutual at SummerSlam, she was in complete support of her husband.  It should also be noted in the beginning that eventhough Lawler tried to point out that Bulldog wore the exact same tights that he wore at SummerSlam, they weren't.  Bulldog used his strength to wear Bret down & even at one point throwing Bret into the ringropes from the superlex position & even delivering his infamous powerslam on the floor.  This match was also one of the rare times during this period of WWE (and Bret's career in general) where there was a heavy amount of blood as Bret was busted open & heavily bleeding after going face first in the steel steps on the floor.  Eventhough their match at SummerSlam is more memorable, I actually enjoyed this encounter better as I thought it they flowed better here."In Your House" Dec. '95Submission Match w/Ken Shamrock as the referee vs. Steve Austin - Just knowing how physical & intense this feud was for the previous months, you got exactly what you expected here in that this was just an all out brawl that went from in the ring to ringside & through the crowd with these men using anything they can get their hands on (ringpost & guardhail & steel steps & ringbell & cables) to just beat the living hell out of each other to the point where Austin was heavily bleeding.  Bret Hart did try to focus on Austin's knee with moves like the figure four on the post while other submissions were tried like a combination of a armbar & head sissors, and boston crab.  This match is a classic & memorable for so many things such as it launched Austin that launched Austin from a superstar to a main event talent, the beginning of the most unique heel turn in wrestling history with Bret Hart, and the highlight image of Austin fighting out of the Sharpshooter with the blood just pouring down from his face.  It should be noted that their was a glitch on the DVD here & the audio is off of a second.WrestleMania 13("Cause Stone Cold Said So")WWE Championship Match vs. Undertaker - This is a rare match between the two due to the fact that it was never shown/released in the United States due to this happenening on the WWE's first ever "European only" PPV and the match was edited out of the VHS tape released in the U.S.  Undertaker got his rematch from SummerSlam months earlier here and Taker was more intense than he usually is by taking the fight right to Bret & brawling down the rampway.  Bret while tried to use heel tactics such as exposing the metal under the turnbuckle (only for it to come back to haunt him later), he did his usual offense of working over Taker's legs to take away the height & power advantage by using moves like the Sharpshooter & the figure four.  Taker did an unusual strategy by focusing on Bret's chest with stomps & stretches & even punches to the heart.  As I said earlier, Taker was very intense in this match & look for revenge against Bret which ultimately cost him in the end because he couldn't control his emotions.  It was great match that finally got some exposure past the limited audience that have seen it for years.One Night Only '97("Tombstone: History Of The Undertaker")Owen Hart Tribute Match vs. Chris Benoit - This match took place in the same arena where Owen Hart fell to his death months earlier at the "Over The Edge" PPV & to showcase just how important this match was, Harley Race did the introductions for this match.  The commentators described this match perfectly early with the phrase "dungeon wrestling."  They were very physical here & used various submissions against each other & turned up the intensity as the match went on with Bret heavily focusing on Benoit's back with headbutts.  In the end, this was a very emotional match & what Mike Tenay said can summerise this better than anything I can say, "Bret & Chris, you made everybody pround.""WCW Nitro" Oct. '99("Hard Knocks: The Chris Benoit Story")Overall, this is probably one of the best DVD sets that WWE has put out & is a fitting tribute to Bret "The Hitman" Hart.

reviewText: After watching Bret Hart for years put on great matches, I had a feeling this DVD set would be good. I had no idea it would be this good.Vince McMahon introduces the documentary part of the set, thanking Bret for putting differences aside. Bret talks about growing up in a wrestling family & watching wrestlers being trained in 'The Dungeon' by Stu Hart. Stu promoted Stampede Wrestling, & some amazing clips are shown like various Bret Hart vs Dynamite Kid matches (great stuff even though they're clips), one of the 1st ladder matches against Bad News Allen (later Bad News Brown in WWe), tag matches with Dean Hart, among others.Stampede Wrestling was soon bought out by WWe, & Bret made his debut after a few tours in Japan. He tells about wanting to turn heel & team with Jim Neidhart, but instead gets a cowboy gimmick & was almost ready to quit when he finally gets to team with Neidhart. They go on to win the Tag Team Titles (twice) before Bret goes into singles action.In single mode, Bret wins the Intercontinental title (also twice). He talks about how, in his opinion (among many others I'm sure) that his match vs British Bulldog at SummerSlam 92 was really his moment when he proved he had what it took to be World Champion.With the Intercontinental Title passed on, he could now focus on the Heavyweight Title. Clips of his non-televised match with Ric Flair (where he won the belt) are shown, including a part where he dislocated his finger & pops it back in place. He talks about wanting to still be one of 'the boys' even though he was Heavyweight Champion & not needing his own separate dressing room , & also how he didn't really feel he deserved the title until his 2nd title win at WrestleMania X, but wanted to prove himself in the meantime at the King Of The Ring tournament.He talks about his feud with Owen & gets quite emotional, saying their feud made them stronger as brothers. Clips of WrestleMania X, their SummerSlam cage match & other moments are shown.His next 3 Heavyweight Title reigns he feels he was more or less holding the belt for someone else, often feeling ignored while Shawn Michaels was groomed to step up, & Bret's great matches against British Bulldog (In Your House - 1995), Diesel, & others were overlooked.The Iron Man Match gets it's own chapter as Bret tells about leading up to the match & the training segments that he feels made him look like he didn't stand much of a chance.After WrestleMania, Bret briefly leaves to do some acting, along which time enters Steve Austin, who calls out Bret. Clips are shown of the build up to their Survivor Series match & their 'I Quit' match at WrestleMania 13.The 'USA vs Canada' feud is looked at quite nicely, where Bret was quite hated in the US, but loved in Canada, which leads into the Survivor Series incident.He shows up in WCW & was almost immediately misused. reviewText: While it is a bit ego driven, I can't agree that it was a shrine to Bret Hart because most of the WWE profiles are ego driven to some extent (with the exception of the recent Jake Roberts DVD).I found the story to be very good. I loved seeing the old Calgary Stampede footage because I've never seen any of it before! Man those guys were vicious and I am glad that Bret had that footage shown.The rest is pretty much his journey through the WWF/WWE over 12 years. I have to agree with him on him being better than a lot of the wrestlers being pushed at the time, especially The Ultimate Warrior! While I did actually like the Warrior, let's face it, a technician he wasn't! Even Hulk Hogan looked like Lou Thez compared to him!Anyway, back to the DVD, I am glad he discussed the Survivor Series '97 incident. Both Vince and Bret, while standing their individual actions that night (you could argue both were out of line), regret that it came to what happened that night.His time in WCW was not memorable to say the least. Even if you think Bret's ego gets in his way, the most die-hard Bret critic would have to admit that WCW didn't really capitalize on Bret's exit from WWE well at all. In fact, his only memorable run was from about October 1999-January 2000 when he finally got a shot at the WCW World title and won it.While not as compelling as the recent Jake Roberts DVD, the bio has plenty of interesting and heartbreaking moments. Now for the extras:DISC 1BRET HARD INTERVIEW MOMENTS*Bret talks about the origin of "The Dungeon" - Interesting to hear WHO dubbed it "The Dungeon"*Bret talks about being away from his family on Halloween - Nothing heartwrenching BUT it does make you think*Bret talks about The Hart Foundation getting along*Bret talks about the Sharpshooter - For the first time, Bret admits what fans have known all along and that his dad Stu DIDN'T come up with The Sharpshooter. Bret admits he first saw the move on his tours of Japan (there is truth to that as not only did Bret tour there many times, the move has its origins in the Orient) and you will be surprised on who showed him the move! Also interesting to note that while he didn't name Sting by name, he did refer to the move by the name Sting called it and that was "The Scorpion Deathlock."*Bret tells a story about Owen crank-calling Stu - VERY FUNNY TALE!*Family Tree - Bret talks about his family from first born to last*Learning The Ropes - Bret discusses his early development in Canada*Sunglasses - Bret discusses his trademark shades*Being a Villian - This is more of a talk about his Hart Foundation days and not really his pro-Canada days.TRIBUTE VIDEOS*Dean Hart Tribute Video - Refers to the Survivor Series 1990*Tribute to Bret's wrestling colleagues who have passed away - We see many faces that Bret has known and worked with over the years such as Owen Hart, Brian Pilliman, Davey Boy Smith, Kerry Von Erich, Big Bossman, Road Warrior Hawk, Junkyard Dog and others. Bret particularly gets emotional when discussing "Ravishing" Rick Rude, "Mr. Perfect" Curt Hennig and, of course, Owen!MATCHES*The Hart Foundation Vs. The British Bulldogs 7/13/85*The Hart Foundation Vs. The Killer Bees 2/17/86DISC 2MATCHES*Bret Hart Vs. Ricky Steamboat - Surprisingly good! Great to see Steamboat again too!*Bret Hart Vs. Ted DiBiase - I haven't watched this match yet but I've always wanted to see these two face off so I will be viewing it soon!*Hart Foundation Vs. The Rockers - Great tag team encounter and I remember viewing this that night! Great to see Demolition again too as they make an apperance here as well.*Hart Foundation Vs. Nasty Boys (WWE World Tag Team Match) - Probably one of the Harts' best bouts in a losing effort.*Bret Hart Vs. Mr. Perfect (WWE I-C title match) - The rise of Bret as a singles star! Classic bout!*Bret Hart Vs. The British Bulldog (WWE I-C title match) - Their legendary SummerSlam meeting. Bret proved that night he could have a good match with anyone as he gave The late Bulldog his best match ever.*Bret Hart VS. Bam Bam Bigelow - This is an overseas match in Spain. Very physical encounter!*Bret Hart Vs. Mr. Perfect (King Of The Ring semifinal match) - This bout may have been better than their original SummerSlam meeting.*Bret Hart Vs. Owen Hart - Their legendary Wrestlemania X encounter. A match I still call the best OPENING match in the history of WrestleMania!DISC 3Bret Hart Vs. Owen Hart - A WWE Title bout from White Plains, NY*Bret Hart Vs. Hakushi - Glad Bret put this one on here because it was very underrated bout and deserves more credit than it gets.Bret Hart Vs. Diesel - Their third WWE Title meeting. This time at the 1995 Survivor Series. The two had meet two other times with no winner.*Bret Hart Vs. The British Bulldog - A rematch from SummerSlam, this time for the WWE Title.Bret Hart Vs. "Stone Cold" Steve Austin - Their famous submission match. While technically the winner, Bret Hart became a heel that night while Austin (the technical loser) began his big run in WWE!*Bret Hart VS. The Undertaker - This is their match from England at One Night Only for the WWE title! It was a rematch from SummerSlam '97 and quite frankly, this bout was better than their SummerSlam meeting (which was quite good by the way).*Bret Hart Vs. Chris Benoit - This was the emotional tribute match to Owen Hart. Other than one match in 1998, this was the first real meeting between the two Canadian legends.Overall, a good buy. The bio was okay but, again, not as good as the Jake Roberts one. Still, the matches and other extras make up for it greatly!

reviewText: Watching the DVD compendium, to the very mention of the name, Bret "The Hit Man" Hart, brought back a lot of childhood memories. From his signature catch phrases such as "The Excellence of Execution," and "The Best There Is, The Best There Was, The Best There Ever Will Be" (Lifted from "The Natural" (1984) movie line) to his metallic visor, leather jacket, and even images of "Monday Night Raw" being the only Brand of World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) (Known then as the "World Wrestling Federation" (WWF)) out on television every week.Probably my greatest Bret Hart memory would be an episode of Raw wherein Bret stepped into the ring as his estranged younger brother, the late Owen "The Rocket" Hart and his ex-brother-in-law The British Bulldog (the late Davey Boy Smith) were about to come to blows.  Bret took it upon himself to patch his relationship with the two men by focusing on the importance of family and his "It's us against America" stand.  This lead to the birth of the new Hart Foundation which also included another brother-in-law and former Tag Team partner, Jim "The Anvil" Neidhart as well as the only American in the group, "the Canadian sympathizer," the late Brian "The Loose Cannon" Pillman.During this period in the history of the WWE, recognizable names such as Shawn Michaels, Triple H, Degeneration X, and "Stone Cold" Steve Austin rose to prominence as "faces."  But it was the new Hart Foundation, led by an aggressive, vindictive, and sadistic (by way of an illegal ring post figure-four leglock that Hart would apply on his opponent entangled legs during matches) Bret Hart that I believe carried the show as "heels." America hated them!  But Canada and Europe sure adored the new Hart Foundation!In the end, despite 23 years in the wrestling business (Stampede Wrestling, WWE, WCW, and various other international productions), I believe that Bret Hart's career ended prematurely (due to a post-concussion syndrome brought about in 99' by a Bill Goldberg Mule Kick to the head).I guess I am still waiting for that magical moment wherein the electric guitar intro of Jimmy Hart's and JJ Maguire's famed "Hitman" theme would be blazing over the arena's PA and out of the shadows would be Bret Hart, clad in his familiar Pink and Black, ready to take on all comers for one final match.Cheers Bret!  Best of luck in your new life and thanks for the memories!
summary: The Bret "The Hit Man" Hart DVD brought back a lot of childhood memories...

reviewText: The Best There Is, The Best There Was, The Best There Ever Will Be3 Disc Collector's Edition (2005)Bret talks about his career and his start. He comes from a long line of wrestlers, it was big in his family in the Hart Dungeon which was their basement training grounds. He started out in Stampede Wrestling and eventually got into the WWE. Bret is said to be one of the greatest technical wrestlers ever from his practically royal upbringing into the business. Getting Bret's point of view on many subjects is very interesting because he comes off as a pretty depressed and jaded individual. Granted, bad things have happened to him but it is still very sad. He has had rivals with many different wrestlers both on stage and off.His career went though many stages first with the Hart Foundation and eventually as a singles competitor, Bret earned the workhorse title - The Intercontinental Championship. Later he moved onto the WWE Championship and becoming an international star and hero standing up for Canadians. Bret's perception of the Iron Man match was pretty different than Shawn's and he seemed pretty upset to lose the belt. Once again, that match is not in this set.The Montreal Screw-job is covered in detail from all angles once more with Bret's side again with some original interview footage from Mr. McMahon. Bret moved to WCW where Ted Turner didn't seem to know what to do with him and didn't utilize him well within that company and wasted the celebrity that he had gained with that acquisition. The story goes into Owen Hart's death and Bret's thoughts and regrets that he wasn't with the WWE company at that time and how it changed his life.Bret was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2006 and Vince McMahon offered to induct Bret's father and then retracted that offer in a series of low events against Bret stirring this rivalry in preparation for WrestleMania 26. It should be an interesting match between a guy as old as Vince and a guy who has had to go through as much recovery as Bret. I just hope they can both do it ok!Matches:These matches skip around and don't go in chronological order and are mostly matches that meant something to Bret for some reason or another. Many of them are not for championships or anything special, they were just an example of his work with a certain person and to the untrained eye, it can be hard to tell what makes them significant. reviewText: Thinking back on the career of Bret Hart it's clear he really is in the elite pack of great performers. This DVD set was a great opportunity to exploit that fact and showcase Bret at his best. They accomplish that, sort of.I'll start with disc 1, the documentary. This part I really enjoyed. Bret speaks openly and honestly in a way that keeps your attention glued to the screen. Rare footage of his early career is shown throughout. He goes over his career in each stage and highlights the hard work he put into achieving what he did. I also like the evaluations he gave of his various opponents and co-workers, honest and no-holds barred. The only downside was skipping over his big feud with Jerry Lawler and the lack of a back story behind the Montreal screw-job. You only get a hint of his hatred toward Shawn Michaels when he talks about their Wrestlemania match. It would've been especially helpful in light of Shawn's new book. As it stands now fans are only getting Shawn's side of events on record. Still, the documentary is ample at 2 and a half hours.My real gripe with this set is partly with the match selection and mostly with the ridiculous editing done by WWE. The match with Steve Austin at Wrestlemania has a bad audio delay that should have been corrected before the set seen the light of day. Note that several macthes they constantly and annoyingly edit out anyone saying "WWF". At least they didn't blur out the old WWF logos. The worst offense is the complete erasure of Jesse Ventura's commentary of the Rockers/Hart Foundation match. Can someone explain WHY? Jesse was one of the best heel commentators ever and the match clearly suffers having to listen to only Vince who might be one the best promoters, but one of the worst announcers in history. This came across as extremely petty to me.Finally on the matches offered, Bret did choose some classics. His matches with Owen and Curt Hennig are superb. However, several were left out that shouldn't have been. No Bret vs. Flair for his first WWF title win? No Bret vs. Jerry Lawler in the "kiss my foot" match? No Bret vs. Shawn Michaels even?! Yet we get Bret vs. Bam Bam Bigelow from Spain. I also recall much better matches with the British Bulldogs than what we got on this set. They give us 5 seconds of the Hart Foundation's tag title win over them with Danny Davis heel turn as referee. A big angle at the time.I know you can't please everybody but this should have been much better and the technical problems are unacceptable. I'm still glad I bought this set but I feel a lot was missing.

reviewText: Just as Ric Flair and Hulk Hogan had dominated pro wrestling in the 1980's, Bret "The Hit Man" Hart had done the same in the 1990's. While talents such as "Stone Cold" Steve Austin and "The Rock" would crossover into the mainstream and become huge stars, neither of them, as talented as they were, dominated the decade from beginning to end like Bret did. This 3-DVD set does a tremendous job in telling the story of one of the greatest pro wrestlers to ever enter the ring.First off, the documentary on the first disc is worth the price of the set alone. From his humble beginnings in Stampede Wrestling to his stellar work with Jim "The Anvil" Neidhart in the Hart Foundation all the way to his singles championship status, nearly all of his career highlights are covered. Having not followed his career until he entered the WWE in 1985, I enjoyed the extensive footage from his early years as you saw Bret develop from a green rookie to a master technician. During the documentary, Bret seems totally at peace with himself and his career despite the circumstances that ended it. The DVD interview moments are also top notch and very informative.As for the matches, most of them are outstanding with a few being all time classics. Back in the mid-80's, the WWE's tag team division was fantastic and is well chronicled here with The Hart Foundation tag matches against both the British Bulldogs and the Killer Bees. The matches with the Rockers and the Nasty Boys are also decent, but don't show the same continuity that the Harts had when they were villains. Then we get the singles matches. Like Flair in his prime, Bret could get a good match out of just about anyone. But if you put him with a guy at or near his level, you had a guaranteed classic. With that in mind, you have two gems each with both his brother Owen Hart and "Mr. Perfect" Curt Hennig. Bret's matches with "British Bulldog" Davey Boy Smith, particularly their Summerslam '92 encounter, are also top notch. As you would expect, his match with Chris Benoit is great also. His matches with Ted DiBiase, Hakushi, and Bam Bam Bigelow are also very good. One thing you notice throughout these matches, which are shown chronologically, are the little things that Bret kept adding to his repertoire. He never stopped trying to improve.Since Bret is my all-time favorite wrestler, it was hard to not give this a 5-star rating. But the reasons that I did had nothing to do with Bret himself. As great as he was, there's only so much you could do with slow plodding big guys like the Undertaker and especially Diesel. The only time these matches, which hover around the 30-minute mark each, are interesting is when Bret is on the offense. Furthermore, there is a one-second sound delay that nearly ruins an awesome match with "Stone Cold" Steve Austin. For a company known for their top notch production, I'm surprised that the WWE let this slip. Despite these faults, this is an excellent collection and just based on the documentary is worth purchasing.
summary: Worth purchasing just for the documentary

THE HART FOUNDATION vs THE BRITISH BULLDOGS (July-13, 1985): Emanating from Madison Square Garden, this isn't what you would call a classic bout between these 2 great teams, but it is a nice little preview of what they are capable of. The dynamic between the 4 men is perfect, with the Bulldogs struggling to contain the constant double-team maneuvers of their opponents, as well as the strength of The Anvil. DaveyBoy Smith plays the face in peril for most of the match, while the Harts (including Jimmy on the outside with his megaphone) do everything to keep Smith in the ring. I've seen better hot tags to Dynamite (where were the suplexes?), while the action here wasn't as crisp as these guys would usually be. Still a great match, despite the disappointing draw result being called as the MSG curfew came up at the 13 minute mark. These guys easily had an extra 20 minutes in them, if not a lot more. WInners No contest. Match Rating 7.5/10.2. THE HART FOUNDATION vs THE KILLER BEES (February-17, 1986-Initially, the structure of this match is actually quite a bit different to most Hart Foundation bouts, as The Killer Bees target & isolate Neidhart for the first 4 minutes. There's some very good tag-team action here & it gets the crowd very much involved. Soon though, the Harts get on top & take control of Brunzell for what seems like an eternity. It's a little too long for my liking & there are a few too many restholds. Although, it doesn't seem to bore the live crowd in attendance, as they frantically anticipate the hot tag to Blair. It eventually comes & it's an understatement to say that the action picks up from there. Blair does everything but get the 3 count as the entertainment picks up tremendously. It was worth the wait & I have to conclude that this was a very good match at the end of the day. BRET HART vs RICKY `THE DRAGON' STEAMBOAT (March-8, 1986): Emanating from Boston Garden, this is an early singles match for the Hitman which took place just prior to WrestleMania 2. In true heel form, Bret attacks Steamboat as the bell rings & gets the early advantage. But it doesn't last too long, as the tremendously over Dragon takes control rather quickly. Ricky actually is the one to slow the pace down as he targets the left arm of Bret. But here & there, especially when or the other is running the ropes, these 2 show the flashes of brilliance (& crispness) that we know they are capable of. As the match settles in, there is some nice back & forth action, with Hart probably having the better of the offense (to the surprise of the fans). A referee bump towards the end leads to a short closing sequence where Steamboat reverses a pinning attempt & gets the victory at the 15 minute mark. The potential was there to see here as Bret showed great ability to wrestle a 15 minute match all by his lonesome against an over face. Isolated though, you know these 2 could do a lot better as the pace was initially a little too methodical & the bout didn't play up to Steamboat's strengths sufficiently. Winner RICKY `THE DRAGON' STEAMBOAT. Match Rating 8.5/10.4. BRET HART vs `THE MILLION DOLLAR MAN' TED DIBIASE (March-8, 1989- Emanating from Odessa-Texas, this match took place after Bret had turned face & started wearing the pink & black. It should also be noted that there is no commentary during this bout. Bret gets the explosive start & attacks Dibiase as the bell rings, almost sneaking the victory once or twice. Quite entertaining to begin with as the Hitman seemingly has an answer for everything the Million Dollar Man throws at him. But a missed charge by Hart results in him getting winded & Dibiase taking control for minutes on end with his interesting mix of strength & technical wrestling that became his trademark in the late 80's & early 90's (although I personally preferred the slimmer & more athletic Dibiase of the early 80's from what I have seen). Back & forth from that point onwards, with each man attempting to outdo the other while attempting numerous pinfalls. Despite Dibiase apparently being blown out (his heavy breathing is evident), these 2 somehow stretch the match out to a 16 minute duration, with Bret's superior athleticism helping the match quality out the longer it progresses. This bout that ends in a double countout, is well put together, if not anything super special. Winner double count out. MAtch Rating 8/10.5. THE HART FOUNDATION vs THE ROCKERS (April-28, 1990-From an episode of `Saturday Nights Main Event', this is a non-stop back & forth entertaining match that simply never lets up from the opening bell. It proves the adaptability of The Hart Foundation & the potential of The Rockers. These 4 guys just go at it at a blistering pace. Hart & Michaels get a good deal of the action which obviously helps, but even Jannetty & Neidhart keep the action moving along at a great pace. Terrific stuff & not completely ruined by the Double DQ result at only the 9 minute mark, when Demolition run in & turn it into a 3 team brawl. WInner double dq. match RAting 8.5/10.6. THE HART FOUNDATION vs THE NASTY BOYS (WrestleMania 7. March-24, 1991): The Hart Foundation came into this bout as the tag champs & without the management of Jimmy Hart, who had since moved over to manage Knobbs & Saggs (or Saggy Knob as I used to call them). I must admit that I was never a fan of The Nasty Boys. In fact, they pretty much constantly bored me. Just to prove it, they make Neidhart look like a quick technician here! Thankfully, this is quite well booked in that it uses Bret a lot & he pretty much carries the bout. Of course, he (& we) have to put up with the boring Nasty Boys offense in the meantime & that brings the match down a peg or 5! The hot tag is eventually made to Neidhart who cleans house. But in a flurry of activity, the Nastys use Jimmy's megaphone & escape with the title win after 12 minutes. Not great, but could have been so much worse. Well booked & sufficiently entertaining. Winners and new wwe tag team champs THE NASTY BOYS. match Rating 7.5/10.7. BRET HART vs `MR PERFECT' CURT HENNIG (SummerSlam. August-26, 1991):  Great start to this match for Perfect's InterContinental Title, with some crisp & entertaining sequences of one-upmanship. Bret's mentioning of Hennig's back injury & those first few moments show what might have been if Hennig had stayed injury-free (both then & in later years)... Especially when Bret was on the top of his game as WWE Champion. That's not to say that they didn't deliver here, as they well & truly did. Just (pardon the pun) perfectly put together, as these 2 guys showed that you could have a great 15+ minute technical match. Great storytelling throughout as both men tried to outdo each other, leading to many exciting nearfalls & some great unpredictability. Bret kicked out of the PerfectPlex (which was surprising at the time) & went to work on Hennig. But to go with the flow of the entire bout, Perfect fought hard & kicked out of many 2 counts. The SharpShooter eventually got the job done though (if a little too quickly & anti-climactically) to win the InterContinental Title at the 18 minute mark. Great stuff from these 2 terrific wrestlers, although I'm certain that if timing & injury permitted, they could do even better. Winner and new wwe itc champ bret hart. Match Rating 9/10.8. BRET HART vs `THE BRITISH BULLDOG' DAVEY BOY SMITH (SummerSlam. August-29, 1992 From the SummerSlam that was held in England, this is my favorite match ever. It was very disappointing to see that DaveyBoy Smith's hugely atmospheric ring entrance in front of his home crowd has been edited out of this DVD! Bret enters this main-event match as the InterContinental Champion. The British crowd are rather amazing, and make me wonder why we haven't seen another ppv outside of North America since. Just the perfect mix of everything, these 2 put together an excellent combination of technical, power & psychological wrestling. This is arguably the bout that elevated Hart to main-event status & gave DaveyBoy Smith a significant push. 26 minutes in length & the final 7 or so is better than anything you will ever see. I think Bobby `The Brain' Heenan best summed this up on commentary when he stated "Is there anything they haven't done?" Winner Bret Hart. Match Rating 10/10.9. BRET HART vs BAM BAM BIGELOW (April-24, 1993 This match is from a live event held in Barcelona-Spain & comes complete with Spanish commentary (I like the sound of the word "Phenomo" & the way they roll their "r's"). Bam Bam's priceless mix of strength & athleticism usually works very well with smaller wrestlers, but I'm not 100% certain that technical wrestling is his forte. For the first 8-10 minutes of this bout, he practically dominates & targets Bret's back. But it's way too methodically paced & only works in batches. A missed headbutt from the top rope gives Bret the chance to quicken the pace, while Bam Bam continues to work on the back. The bout is much more successful at this stage, but ends too quickly at just the 12 minute mark with the Hitman nicely rolling Bam Bam up with a victory roll from a headscissors position for the win. Winner bret Hart/ Match Rating 7.5/10.10. BRET HART vs `MR PERFECT' CURT HENNIG (King Of The Ring. June-13, 1993): This was the semi-final match of the annual tournament & the 2nd of 3 bouts that Bret wrestled on the night. The first couple of minutes of this match is almost identical to their SummerSlam '91 bout, and that's not necessarily a bad thing! This isn't entirely a duplicate of the match from approximately 2 years earlier though, as Hennig controls this bout a little more. Plus, he had obviously since learnt the art of the knife-edge chop from Ric Flair, as he uses it a fair bit. Being picky, the structure & psychology of this bout doesn't quite work, as Bret hurts his knee on the outside & looks in all sorts of trouble. But then, only a couple of minutes later, he is on the offense & working on Hennig's legs! When it finally evens out, Perfect goes for a couple of sleeper-holds, which makes sense for him to recover from his sore leg, but doesn't exactly increase the entertainment aspect of this bout! Then, out of nowhere at the 17 minute mark, Hennig starts to attack Bret's injured hand (from his first match that night)! A great suplex counter to the outside gets the crowd on their feet, and it's quickly followed up by a roll-up reversal at the 19 minute mark to give the victory to Bret. Still a very good match, but wasn't quite right storytelling & psychology-wise. Sufficiently different from their 1991 match, but not as good. Winner bret hart. match Rating 8.5/10.11. BRET HART vs OWEN HART (WrestleMania 10. March-20, 1994This was a strange feeling as we basically had a main-event opening a huge pay-per-view. Similarly to the match against The British Bulldog, there was a nice family storyline build-up here, although it was probably stronger in this match, as Bret & Owen weren't both faces & the WWE really spent some time on this feud. Throughout this bout, there was a constant game of one-upmanship (especially on Owen's behalf) that was just so entertaining to watch. In fact, it was so good that you almost couldn't help cheer for some of Owen's bigger moves during the match. They wisely didn't go all out from the very beginning, instead choosing to gradually build up the pace and, for that matter the spots as well, as the match progressed.A turning point occurs at the 13 minute mark when Bret hurts his knee on a dive to the outside. Owen perfectly targets it & fortunately keeps the moves (whether for impact or submission) coming at a good pace, rather than slowing the pace down. Nor does it take too long for Bret to make the comeback with a great variety of offense. A nice closing sequence sees a battle of SharpShooters followed by Owen's unpredictable pinfall counter to a victory roll at the 20 minute mark. It's a match that probably doesn't scream out 10 out of 10 to some, but when all is considered (the feud, the storyline, the psychology, the crispness, the pacing, the structure, the entertainment & the unpredictability), it's hard to rate it anything else. Both men come out of this match looking supremely good. Winner Owen Hart. Match Rating 10/10.Disk 312. BRET HART vs OWEN HART (September-29, 1994 This match from White Plains - New York was televised on some show called `The Action Zone'. It was for Bret's WWE Championship & took place after their cage match at SummerSlam (not on this DVD). Doesn't quite have the same impact as their WrestleMania 10 bout (or the cage match for that matter), but it still has some great crisp action, terrific counters & reversals and good overall entertainment value. Two edits due to commercial breaks definitely don't help the flow of the bout, but we still get to see 14 minutes of very good footage. Jim `The Anvil' Neidhart gets involved on behalf of Owen, but DaveyBoy Smith negates him & eventually pushes Owen off the top rope to enable Bret to get the pinfall win. Hard to rate as it it's a television match that obviously doesn't stack up to the WrestleMania 10 or SummerSlam bouts, but it's still very solid & definitely a good watch. Winner Bret Hart. Match Rating 8/10.13. BRET HART vs HAKUSHI (In Your House. May-14, 1995 This was the first of 2 matches on the same night for Bret, as he was to face Jerry `The King' Lawler later on. Hakushi was a pretty good & very athletic Japanese wrestler that the WWE brought in for about a year. Following a couple of early communication breakdowns that resulted in some messy looking wrestling, these 2 settled into a rather nice pace. I'm unsure that the bout made great use of Hakushi's unorthodox offense, although we do see a nice Asai Moonsault & a couple of other very athletic moves. Not the perfect structure either as I would have preferred more back & forth action. I may be a little nit-picky though, as this was still a rather entertaining match, especially towards the end when both men worked very hard to win the fans over. The Hitman gets the win with a victory roll at the 14 minute mark. It actually felt longer than that, which is usually not a good sign, but this was still pretty good. Winner Bret Hart. Match Rating 8/10.14. BRET HART vs KEVIN `DIESEL' NASH (Survivor Series. November-19, 1995): This was a `No Disqualification' match for Diesel's WWE Championship (which he had held for 51 weeks!). The bout starts off predictably with Nash using his superior size & strength to overpower The Hitman. In fact, Bret spends basically the first 8 minutes running away from Diesel on the outside... very unsuccessfully, I might add! Bret turns the tide with some biting & eye gouging (yep, you read that correctly), and then predictably targets the big mans leg with precision offense. Obviously, this slows the pace of the bout down a little, but not so much that the match ever becomes boring. Bret then has the interesting idea of using a microphone cable to tie Diesel's ankle to the steel ringpost. This leads to multiple chairshots to seemingly have the big man out for the count. But Nash eventually creates enough separation to enable him to untie himself & subsequently use that same cable to choke Bret. What follows is some decent, if awkward (due to over-selling), back & forth action, highlighted by Hart going through the Spanish Announce Table in a rather simple, yet very effective, spot. A little unbelievably, Bret rolls up Diesel soon after to get the pinfall victory at the 25 minute mark to win the title. Different type of `No DQ' match that provides good variation & is quite entertaining. But it doesn't match up to the April '96 `No DQ' match that Diesel had with Shawn Michaels. Winner and new wwe champ bret hart. Match Rating 8.5/10.15. BRET HART vs 'THE BRITISH BULLDOG' DAVEY BOY SMITH (In Your House. December-17, 1995 This match was for Bret's WWE Championship & DaveyBoy Smith had recently turned heel & was managed by Jim Cornette. It should also be noted that Bret's sister Diana, who was married to the Bulldog, accompanied Smith to the ring. Nice beginning to this bout, but the Bulldog then drags it down with resthold after resthold. It's not until about the 9 minute mark that Bret thankfully gets in any great sequence of offense (including a nice piledriver). But DaveyBoy regains control after countering a superplex & attacking Hart on the outside (including busting him wide open). Back in the ring, the Bulldog gets multiple 2 counts with a piledriver, a vertical suplex, a press slam & a diving headbutt. He even throws in a Bow `N' Arrow for good measure! What follows is some good back & forth action that is entertaining, despite being a little imperfect & not quite meshing successfully. DaveyBoy does hit a nice running powerslam on the outside, but back in the ring he falls victim to a superplex, which leads into many good nearfalls. Bret eventually gets the victory at the 21 minute mark with a rollup (he won a few too many of his big bouts that way!). There are flaws in this match & it doesn't compare too well to their SummerSlam '92 bout. But these 2 eventually work so hard here that they win you over. Winner and sdtill wwe champ bret hart. Match Rating 8/10.16. BRET HART vs `STONE COLD' STEVE AUSTIN (WrestleMania 13. March-23, 1997): This was called a `Submissions Match' which basically meant that you had to win by submission. It also had a 'No Disqualificaion' stipulation attached to it. Making his WWE debut as the referee here was former UFC Champion Ken Shamrock. This was a great feud that began when Stone Cold called out Bret while he was away from the WWE. This resulted in a very good bout at Survivor Series '96 & Austin subsequently cheating Hart out of a Royal Rumble win. Hart began the match as a face & Austin as a heel, but come the end of the bout, the tables would be turned as this was one of the best booked matches of all time!These 2 are at it before the bell & the intensity is top notch. It doesn't take too long before they are into the crowd & the last thing on their mind out there is a submission hold! Following a couple of spots involving the steel ring steps, the combatants are back into the ring at the 6 minute mark, at which time Bret precisely targets Austin's knee. A Stone Cold Stunner out of nowhere stems the tide, but Bret everually regains control with a ringpost figure 4 leglock. Back & forth it goes as Stone Cold gets back on top with a couple of chairshots. This leads to the first attempted submission hold at the 12 minute mark, as Austin goes for a strange looking armbar followed by a Boston Crab. Back on the outside, Austin gets Irish Whipped into the steel guardrail & is busted wide open. Bret then attacks the forehead wound, before heading back to the knee. Despite all this, 'Stone Cold' gets a second wind & puts together some intense offense, before trying to choke the Hitman with an extension cord. But the nearby ringbell saves Bret & he quickly follows up with the SharpShooter. After almost 2 minutes of struggling to fight out of it, a bloodied Austin passes out & referee Shamrock calls for the bell.Any questions as to whether this is a 10 out of 10 match is almost negated by that infamous perfect shot of Austin having blood dripping down his face while attempting to struggle out of the SharpShooter. But it wasn't just the ending that was perfectly booked, it was almost the entire bout. The heated feud really came through, the action was intense, entertaining & rather original, plus a tremendous story was told. If anything, it could have lasted a little longer than the 22 minutes that it did, while it also could have possibly had a little more technical wrestling involved considering the participants. But that is very much nitpicking, I can assure you. Winner Bret Hart. Match Rating 10/10.17. BRET HART vs THE UNDERTAKER (One Night Only. September-20, 1997 This ppv was actually a bit of an experiment, as it emanated from Birmingham-England & the partially split crowd actually made the bout quite interesting. It was fairly similarly structured to the SummerSlam match which happened a month earlier, but the big difference was that the earlier bout had Shawn Michaels as the Special Guest Referee. Thus, this match lacked a little unpredictability, plus HBK's entertaining antics, in comparison. The bout was natural & solid, but over-long. It began with some nice intense moves that were full of impact. The psychology of the bout was ok, as 'Taker targetted the chest of the Hitman with both blows & submission moves. In response, Bret predictably targets the phenom's legs. This slows the pace down a fair bit, although the action is sufficiently constant. Towards the end, there are a couple of nice counters to the opponent's finishers. But it all goes on for too long, as Bret retains the title at the 29 minute mark after he gets his neck caught between the middle & top ropes, and the referee disqualifies The Undertaker for continuing to attack him. A disappointing ending to a solid match. Winner by dq Bret Hart. Match Rating 8/10.18. BRET HART vs CHRIS BENOIT (WCW Monday Nitro. October-4, 1999 This was the Owen Hart Tribute Match that took place at the same arena in which Bret's brother lost his life. This bout is almost surreal & it really does take a lot of time to both the viewing & live audience to get into it. Because of this, I believe that Benoit & Hart opened the bout with more of a clinic, than a match. They are very technical & very respectful for the first 5 or so minutes. In fact, the first half of it's 23 minute duration (excluding commercial breaks) is a little meandering, but technically proficient. But it's just too difficult to ignore the crispness of the performed moves, as it is superb. It's also great to see Benoit pull out a couple of moves here & there that he doesn't do anymore (post neck surgery). From about the 10 minute mark onwards, we see some great counter & chain wrestling, as you would expect from these two. And they're both very professional, as the competition aspect of the match does come into play very well. A tough one to rate because of the match circumstances, but definitely very good, despite the strange psychology & lack of a cracking pace. Winner Bret Hart.
