reviewText: THE SHORT: Loads of great matches from one of the best technical wrestlers around, offset by a documentary that is interesting but told all from Bret's point of view. As a fan of Bret's I came away from this dvd set appreciating his talent all the more, while surprisingly also believing some of the criticisms against him a bit more as well.THE LONG: Either you respect Bret for his unquestionable mat abilities and understand his side of the Montreal screwjob or you don't because you believe that he is too full of himself and got has comeuppance. This dvd paradoxically caters to both sides of the camp. While the matches are entertaining as always, in all objectivity I must admit that the documentary too often comes across as egotistical and self-serving. Let's put it this way- I was shocked that Shawn Michael's dvd was by far the more objective and critical of the two.Let's cover the documentary first. For the zero people who don't already know, Bret was a wrestler in the WWE for years and left under harsh terms, having been humiliated in a match that stripped him of his championship in a way that he had been promised would not occur. This is the Montreal screwjob as it is known. There are two sides of this event- those who see Bret's departure as a double-cross by a deceitful businessman pushing fairness aside for his own interests, and those who believe that Bret's head had swollen at his own sense of importance and had to be forced down. Though the end result never should have happened the way it did and both sides now admit to as much, there is of course a degree of truth to both arguments.In this documentary, which runs around 2 hours, Bret does most of the talking as he takes us through his career. For fans such as myself this is very welcome- not only is it nice to see a wrestler narrating his own history for us, but Bret deserves at least that much. His greatest regret had always been not having a satisfying archive of his legacy, and now he does. I say good for him. He quietly and intelligently covers the highlights, and of course the most impactful statements are the most emotional ones, as he describes his rivalry with Shawn Michaels and the loss of his brother Owen. Aside from some random clips of Bret's tenure in Stampede wrestling (which go, unnarrated, for some time and should have been reserved for the match portion of the dvd), this documentary is compelling.However to objectively appreciate this release one must also realize that there is hardly any critical or open-minded examination of Bret's career, which makes it harder for an objective viewer to appreciate and in fact easier to disregard than it should be. From the moment the documentary starts, Vince Mcmahon magnanimously thanks Bret for having the integrity to return to the WWE to record this dvd release. This is appreciated yet one wonders if this wasn't something Bret demanded. If the dvd was more even-handed it wouldn't be an issue, but as it is one wonders whether to respect this or roll their eyes.But then began Bret's narrative, and I was a bit taken aback. Bret was always very confident and maybe a bit arrogant at times, but I believe his workrate backed that up and the events of Montreal were in fact completely unwarranted. While I still believe that things shouldn't have happened the way they did, I can't help but admit that Bret's own words on this dvd make me take his side a bit less fiercely. While it's nice to hear him tell his own story, he does so in a way that at times made it clear why there is a camp that considers him self-absorbed and whiny.A few comments about how great a wrestler he is is fine. He IS a great wrestler, and there's that warranted confidence. But I then started to notice more comments that were hard to defend. There are several occasions where he describes the championship as his own, something he deserved, and his reigns cut shorter than he believed they should have been. Whether I agree or not, it's hard not to prefer the humility of similar stories from people like the Rock or Mick Foley (who, it should be noted, are both fans of Bret). There are other awkward moments as Bret nitpicks on the way the WWE promoted his great 1996 championship bout with Shawn Michaels, complaining that the clips of his training were not as flattering as he wanted while Shawn was filmed looking like a million bucks. And of course when it comes down to Montreal, I don't blame Bret in the slightest for telling the story exactly how he wants to. But without opposing opinions and with Bret speaking so candidly, it does create an aura of complete self-importance at times.Again, it can be argued that this is the point- this is Bret's chance to have the spotlight and say exactly what he's wanted to say, no holding back. In this respect I have monumental appreciation that this opportunity came about. But by allowing Bret to speak his uncensored mind, I admit this does lay bare comments and opinions that give weight to some of the harsh criticisms made against him. From what I understand, Bret (understandably) required a large portion of creative control over this dvd set, and therefore if I understand the criticisms against him a bit more now, it is his own fault.The matches on this dvd set are fantastic, as can be expected of a performer of Bret's caliber. Some have said that the match selections are biased, and they include mostly fights with friends of Bret's. While this is a matter of opinion, it's hard to complain about being offered matches such as Bret vs. Hennig, Davey Boy Smith, Benoit or Owen. It IS true that Shawn Michaels makes nary an appearance here, though most of their noteworthy confrontations are available elsewhere on dvd format. And frankly, I don't really want their iron man match, fantastic though it is, taking up one hour of this set while also on my Wrestlemania 12 disc.Ultimately, it's like this- if you're a fan of Bret's wrestling, there are plenty of matches here to validate the purchase. Frankly as a fan of talented wrestling I found this alone to be worth the money. And if you are completely on Bret's side of things, you won't have much to complain about. Bret always wanted to supervise a compilation of his career with the WWE, and as a fan of his I am thankful that he was given this opportunity. He did it his way in the end, and I can't disrespect that. I guess the only problem I have is that new fans unfamiliar with the Hitman may look at this and have the ammunition needed to declare him an arrogant whiner.But at the end of the day, the matches are of him, and the words are his own. It is what it is. And though I hoped for a more affable and humble Bret, I don't have any less respect for him for being himself and letting us be the judge. Now that part's up to you.
summary: An interesting but one-sided documentary coupled with excellent matches

reviewText: If you're a Bret Hart fan, this DVD is a must-have.  If you're a modern fan who's never had the pleasure of seeing Bret Hart in the ring, and you're curious as to what the hype is about, buy it.Bret Hart gives his account in a very comprehensive documentary about his life and journey through wrestling.  He re-lives the highest of his highs, lowest of his lows, and holds back almost no emotion.  Is it a biased account?  Of course it is!  You're getting one man's point of view, when there are most definitely diverging points of view on the controversies in his career.You shouldn't approach this with the hopes of getting an unbiased account of things like the Montreal Screwjob.  Get this as a look into the point of view of another man, as we've heard McMahon and Michaels's versions of this story.  Buy this, and buy HBK's book if you want balance.  Or buy the "Wrestling with Shadows" documentary.  This is meant to be a look into the life of Bret Hart through his own viewpoint.Anyway, aside from Hart's riveting life story, there are a number of his finest matches in the Extras section of this DVD.  They include:Hart Foundation vs. Killer BeesHart Foundation vs. RockersBret Hart vs. Ricky SteamboatBret Hart vs. Ted DibiaseHart Foundation vs. Nasty Boys (The Hart Foundation's last match)Bret Hart vs. Mr. Perfect (Curt Hennig) for the IC title, 1991vs. British Bulldog Davey Boy Smith - 1992, IC title match at Wembley Stadiumvs. Bam Bam Bigelow - Barcelona House Show, 1993vs. Mr. Perfect - King of the Ring Semifinals, 1993vs. Owen Hart - WrestleMania Xvs. Owen Hart - Action Zone, late 1994vs. Hakushi - In Your House I, 1995vs. Diesel - Survivor Series, 1995, World Title Matchvs. British Bulldog - In Your House V, 1995, World Title Matchvs. Stone Cold Steve Austin - WrestleMania 13vs. Chris Benoit - Monday Nitro, Owen Hart Tribute Match, 1999Overall the matches are great.  It really shows you why the Hitman has the reputation he has today.  There are some omissions, but most of his truly great matches are there.  The WM 10 match with Owen was the most essential, IMO, and it made the cut.Overall, this is just a great DVD with both a compelling story and a fun compilation of matches.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: Out of all of the past and present wrestling technicians that has came through WWE (Ric Flair, Triple H, Mr. Perfect, Ricky Steamboat, Chris Benoit, Kurt Angle, Chris Jericho, etc.), Bret "The Hit-Man" Hart has to be argubably the greatest in anybody's book. Bret could take the most simpliest guy and make him appear like he was a 5 star main eventer. That's how good Bret Hart was. Bret Hart had all the tools to make it in the business. And he certainly did. This is what you will find on the three discs:DISC 1The documentary portion of this set is very good. Lasting between a hour and a half to two hours, you will hear from Bret himself, current and past WWE superstars such Chris Benoit, Road Warrior Animal, Christian, Jim Ross, Eric Bischoff, Jimmy Hart, and also from Mr. McMahon as well. Bret goes in depth about the most important aspects of his career. Starting out in Canadian Stampede wrestling up in Calgary and winning the tag team titles with his brother and also winning their world title there. Coming to the WWE and eventually teaming up with Jim "The Anvil" Neidhart and forming the Hart Foundation. Having great tag matches against legendary Tag Teams such as The Bulldogs, Road Warriors, Killer Bees, The Rockers, & Demolition. Finally breaking away from Jim and becoming a single's wrestler. Winning the IC Title and his matches with Mr. Perfect and the British Bulldog. Then soon winning the WWE Title for the first time from Ric Flair and the rest of Bret's WWE Title reigns. His feuds with Owen Hart, Shawn Michaels, & Stone Cold Steve Austin. The whole deal invloving the U.S.A. vs. Canada storyline with Bret and the new Hart Foundation. The controversary of the 1997 Survivor Series surrounding Bret, Vince McMahon, and WCW. Bret debuting in WCW and not having the career there that he wanted. His thoughts about Owen's death and having the Owen Hart Tribute Match with Chris Benoit. Lastly, finally winning the WCW Title but soon having his career and title reign cut short after suffering a concussion in a match against Bill Goldberg.Extra's from DISC 1Bret talking about the origin of "The Dungeon"Bret being away from his family on Halloween nightBret talking about how well the Hart Foundation got alongBret learning and adopting the SharpshooterBret tells a story about Owen prank calling their father Stu HartBret talking about The Hart Family TreeBret getting trained and getting into professional wrestlingBret discussing where the Sunglasses came fromBret's thoughts about being a villianHart Foundation Vs. reviewText: The Bret Hart DVD is one you really need to own. With three disks full of matches [18 to be exact] and an emotionally filled documentary of the life of the Hitman, this just proves that no one can make a DVD quite like Bret Hart and the WWE.The documentary goes into detail on how Bret started his career. His early days in Stampede Wrestling are shown in some great old school clips. His starting days in WWE where he teamed with Jim "The Anvil" Neidhart to form the Hart Foundation is shown as well as when he won the intercontinental title and started his solo career.The documentary ends with clips from the Survivor Series famous incident in 1997, and when Hart went to WCW and wasn't used correctly. It shows an emotional moment with Owen Hart's death and the tribute match Bret had with Chris Benoit, all the way to when Hart had to retire after his match with Bill Goldberg. Bret makes sure the viewer of the DVd got what he or she paid for and the DVD delivered in my opinion.As for the extra matches, they are off the hook:Matches from Disk One:The Hart Foundation vs. The British Bulldog:Nice match that showed fast paced action near the end and some funny commentary by Gorilla Monsoon. The ending comes when the time limit ends, but besides that this is a good match. 8/10The Hart Foundation vs. The Killer Bees:Again, another good match where The Anvil and Hart just dominate for 80 percent of the match. The Killer Bees make a comeback but again, the time limit expires and the match is a draw. 8/10Disk Two Matches:Intercontinental ChampionshipBret Hart vs. The British Bulldog:The best match on the second disk. This was an incredible match between two of the very best. Over 80,000 people cheered for both men and technical wrestling was at it's finest. The Bulldog and Hitman also had a lot of counter skills and fast paced action all throughout the match. The Bulldog wins and the celebration was awsome. 10/10Bret Hart vs. Bam Bam Bigelow:The entire match was in Spanish as they were in Spain. Not much of a match, but some powerhouse moves by Bam Bam and some fast paced moves by Bret the end comes near and Bret wins. 8/10King of the Ring Semifinal MatchBret Hart vs. Mr. Perfect:A great match between these two. Some great back and forth action and this is one of the better ones of the disk. Bret would go on to wrestle several matches that night and beat Mr. Perfect to advance into the final round of the King of the Ring. Some good sportsman ship at the end. 9/10World Tag Team ChampionshipThe Hart Foundation vs. The Nasty Boys:Okay match but it's weird seeing the Nasty Boys in the WWE. Jimmy  Hart is at it again with his megaphone and the crowd was really into this match all through its entirety. Look for a celebrity in the beginning when he was young. The Nasty Boys win with the help of a helmet. 8.5/10Hart Foundation vs. The Rockers:Cool seeing Bret and Shawn fight back in the old days before they were mega-stars, but the entire match itself was just a few minutes long before the old tag team, Demolition, come down to ringside and cause a double disqualification. 5/10 Fast moves but way to short.Intercontinental ChampionshipBret Hart vs. Mr. Perfect:Great Match, very legendary as Rowdy Roddy Piper was also on commentary as well. The entire action is back and forth and after Bret puts Perfect into the sharpshooter, Perfect gives up and Bret wins the title for the first time. 9/10Wrestlemania 10Bret Hart vs. Owen Hart:Great match, both men worked so well together. Owen continued to play the great heel role and even showed some great wrestling ability that he was known for. The ending was a surprise as Owen gets the pin out of nowhere for the win over a shocked Bret. 9/10 The King's commentary during the match was a little annoying, but other than that this was great.WWE Championship MatchNo DisqualificationsBret Hart vs. Diesel:Unique match, a chair was used throughout the entire match but it was cushioned which was the only bad thing. Bret even ties Diesel's leg to the ring rope and pummels away on him. A cool spot happened though when Bret was sent off the apron through the announce table. The ending was a little weak though as Bret got the pin out of nowhere after Diesel failed to powerbomb him. 7.5/10Submission MatchBret Hart vs. Stone Cold Steve Austin:The editing is bad for this one. Sure we get Bret Hart vs. Bam Bam in Spain, but for the match that made Stone Cold a tough son of a b*tch, the sound is just one and a half seconds off. You see Stone Cold hit Bret in the back with a chair then hear the impact one second later. It is really annoying but if you have the match on another disk then you won't mind if that much. But be warned, if this is one of the main reasons why you bought this DVD you need to learn not to mind the second dealy. 10/10 Best match choice in the entire disk collection.Owen Hart Tribute MatchBret Hart vs. Chris Benoit:Emotional match to show the love and respect both men had for the legendary performer known as Owen Hart. The wrestling is great and both men really put their all into showing their respect for Owen. Bret wins the match but both men celebrate in the end as the crowd gives them a big ovation. 9/10 Emotional match but really a nice touch to end the choice of matches.There are a lot of other matches on the disk but I thought these were the best of them all.The Other Matches Are:Bret Hart vs. Jimmy Superfly Snuka [Great Match]Bret Hart vs. Owen Hart for the WWE Title [Just as good as the other one]Bret Hart vs. The Undertaker One Night Only in London [Really Long Match but all right]Plus more.This is an amazing well put together disk and you need to own it for the matches listed above. Great DVD, Highly reccomended.
